fixed-vs-random

Source: vignettes/fixed-vs-random.Rmd
fixed-vs-random.Rmd
library(causalx)
library(lme4)
#> Loading required package: Matrix
library(parameters)
library(broom.mixed)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
iris2 = iris[-c(1:10),] |> as_tibble() # create an imbalance in obs counts by species
lm1 = lm(Sepal.Length ~ Species - 1, data = iris2)
lm2 = lmer(Sepal.Length ~ (1|Species), data = iris2)

coef(lm1)
#>     Speciessetosa Speciesversicolor  Speciesvirginica 
#>            5.0425            5.9360            6.5880
coef(lm2)
#> $Species
#>            (Intercept)
#> setosa        5.051849
#> versicolor    5.935264
#> virginica     6.581257
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "coef.mer"

lm2 |> broom.mixed::tidy(effects="ran_vals")
#> # A tibble: 3 × 6
#>   effect   group   level      term        estimate std.error
#>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>      <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1 ran_vals Species setosa     (Intercept)  -0.804     0.0827
#> 2 ran_vals Species versicolor (Intercept)   0.0791    0.0741
#> 3 ran_vals Species virginica  (Intercept)   0.725     0.0741

Here’s a causal model simulation:

m = 500
n = 5
person_data = tibble(
  id = 1:m,
  c = rnorm(n = m),
  x0 = rnorm(n = m) + c
)

obs_data = 
  person_data |> 
  group_by(id, x0, c) |> 
  summarize(
    .groups = "drop",
    obs = 1:n
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    x = x0 + rnorm(m*n),
    y = x + c + rnorm(m*n),
    
  ) |> 
  group_by(id, x0, c) |> 
  mutate(xbar = mean(x)) |> 
  ungroup()

lm_true = lm(y ~ x + c, data = obs_data)
lm1 = lm(y ~ x, data = obs_data)

lm2 = lmer(y ~ x + (1|id), data = obs_data)
lm3 = lmer(y ~ x + xbar + (1|id), data = obs_data)
lm4 = lm(y ~ x + factor(id), data = obs_data)
coef(lm4) |> head()
#> (Intercept)           x factor(id)2 factor(id)3 factor(id)4 factor(id)5 
#>  -0.4181872   0.9748496  -0.4020199   0.3565376  -0.5549679   0.9051089
fixef(lm2)
#> (Intercept)           x 
#>  0.02755205  1.16874023
coef(lm1)
#> (Intercept)           x 
#>   0.0251666   1.3358573

sum1 = summary(lm1)
sum2 = summary(lm2)
# sum3 = summary(lm3)

Even though xbar and id are multicollinear, the model massively benefits from being helped to understand the non-causal relationship between id and the outcome, which is approximately blocked by xbar. This is an example of the usefulness of group-mean centering.

It’s a lot easier to get the right answer once you
